messages.content:
Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

Shortly after my wedding 30 years ago, I went on a road trip with my husband. 
We started in New York City and drove across the entire country to San Francisco. 
There, at a tiny souvenir shop, my husband found a bracelet charm in the shape of the Golden Gate Bridge. 
When I saw this cute little charm, I thought it would be a great souvenir to remember the trip, so I bought it to hang on my silver bracelet. 
This turned out to be the beginning of a lifelong tradition.
After a few months, my husband and I got a chance to travel to Moscow. 
There, we happened to find a tiny St. Basil’s Cathedral charm and it reminded me of the first charm from San Francisco. 
Without a moment’s hesitation, we bought it to add to the bracelet. 
Since then, we have managed to find the perfect charm on every trip. 
We now have nearly 20 different charms―one from each trip.
We have a Taj Mahal charm from India, a Parthenon charm from Greece, and even an elephant charm from Kenya. 
As my children grew up, they helped choose some of the charms, so our whole family can look back at every trip we’ve taken together.

Shortly after my wedding 30 years ago, / I / went on / a road trip / with my husband. 
30년 전 결혼식 직후 / 나는 / 떠났다 / 자동차 여행을 / 남편과 함께
We / started / in New York City / and / drove across / the entire country / to San Francisco. 
우리는 / 출발했다 / 뉴욕에서 / 그리고 / 운전했다 / 나라 전체를 가로질러 / 샌프란시스코까지 
There, / at a tiny souvenir shop, / my husband / found / a bracelet charm / in the shape / of the Golden Gate Bridge. 
그곳에서 / 아주 작은 기념품 가게에서 / 남편은 / 발견했다 / 팔찌 장식물을 / 금문교 모양의
When I / saw / this cute little charm, / I / thought / it / would be / a great souvenir / to remember the trip, / so / I / bought / it / to hang / on my silver bracelet. 
내가 / 봤을 때 / 이 작고 귀여운 장식물을 / 나는 / 생각했다 / 그것이 / 될 것이라고 / 좋은 기념품이 / 여행을 기념할 / 그래서 / 나는 / 샀다 / 그것을 / 걸기 위해 / 내 은팔찌에
This / turned out to be / the beginning / of a lifelong tradition.
이것은 / 결국 되었다 / 시작이 / 평생 이어지는 전통의
After a few months, / my husband and I / got / a chance / to travel / to Moscow. 
몇 달 뒤 / 남편과 나는 / 가졌다 / 기회를 / 여행 할 / 모스크바로 
There, / we / happened to find / a tiny St. Basil’s Cathedral charm / and / it  reminded / me / of the first charm / from San Francisco. 
그곳에서 / 우리는 / 우연히 발견했다 / 아주 작은 성 바실리 성당 장신구를 / 그리고 / 그것은 / 생각나게 했다 / 내게 / 첫 번째 장식물을 / 샌프란시스코에서 샀던
Without a moment’s hesitation, / we / bought / it / to add / to the bracelet. 
한 순간의 망설임 없이 / 우리는 / 샀다 / 그것을 / 추가하기 위해 / 팔찌에
Since then, / we / have managed to find / the perfect charm / on every trip. 
그때부터 / 우리는 / 용케 찾아내왔다 / 완벽한 장식품을 / 모든 여행에서
We / now / have / nearly 20 different charms /―one from each trip.
우리는 / 이제 / 가지고 있다 / 거의 20개의 다른 장식품을 / 각 여행에서 하나씩
We / have / a Taj Mahal charm / from India, / a Parthenon charm / from Greece, / and / even / an elephant charm / from Kenya. 
우리는 / 가지고 있다 / 타지마할 장식물을 / 인도에서 온 / 파르테논 장식물을 / 그리스에서 온 / 그리고 / 심지어 / 코끼리 장식물을 / 케냐에서 온
As my children / grew up, / they / helped / choose / some of the charms, / so / our whole family / can look back / at every trip / we /’ve taken / together.
나의 아이들이 / 자라면서 / 그들은 / 도와줬다 / 몇가지 장신구를 고르는 것을 / 그래서 / 온 가족이 / 되돌아 볼 수 있다 / 모든 여행을 / 우리가 / 다녀왔던 / 함께

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

Whether it’s for uploading status messages and selfies on social networks or for looking up the best restaurants, staying connected online is not an option but a must for many travelers these days. 
 However, finding an affordable way to get a reliable connection when traveling overseas can be very challenging. 
 So I buy a SIM card when I get to a foreign country. 
 At a reasonable price I can get the same connection speed as the locals. That’s not all. 
 Because countries all have different telecommunication companies, each SIM card is a unique souvenir of my trip to that country. 
 What’s more, as SIM cards don’t take up luggage space, they’re very easy to take home. 
 I have a collection of nine already, and it’s growing fast!

Whether it /’s / for uploading status messages and selfies / on social networks / or / for looking up / the best restaurants, / staying connected online / is / not an option / but a must / for many travelers / these days. 
그것이 / 상태메세지와 셀카를 올리기 위해서든 / 소셜 네트워크에 / 또는 / 찾기 위해서든 / 최고의 식당을 / 온라인에 연결된 상태를 유지하는 것은 / 선택사항이 아니라 / 필수 사항이다 / 많은 여행자들에게 / 요즘
However, / finding an affordable way / to get a reliable connection / when traveling overseas / can be very challenging. 
그러나 / 적당한 가격의 방법을 찾는 것은 / 믿을 만한 연결을 얻는 / 해외여행을 할 때 / 매우 힘들 수 있다
So / I / buy / a SIM card / when I / get / to a foreign country. 
그래서 / 나는 / 산다 / SIM카드를 / 내가 / 도착할 때 / 외국에
At a reasonable price / I / can get / the same connection speed / as the locals. 
적당한 가격에 / 나는 / 얻을 수 있다 / 똑같은 연결 속도를 / 현지인들과 같은
That / ’s not all. 
이것이 / 전부가 아니다
Because countries / all have different telecommunication companies, / each SIM card / is / a unique souvenir / of my trip / to that country. 
나라들은 / 모두 가지고 있기 때문에 / 다른 통신회사를 / 각각의 SIM카드는 / 독특한 기념품이다 / 내 여행의 / 그 나라로의
What’s more, / as SIM cards / don’t take up / luggage space, / they /’re very easy / to take home. 
게다가 / SIM카드는 / 차지하지 않기 때문에 / 짐 공간을 / 그들은 / 매우 쉽다 / 집에 가져가기에
I / have / a collection of nine / already, / and / it / ’s growing / fast!
나는 / 가지고 있다 / 아홉 개의 모음을 / 이미 / 그리고 / 그것은 / 늘어나고 있다 / 빠르게

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

Another thing I collect might sound strange: Wi-Fi hotspots. 
Whenever I’m in a place I want to remember, I purposely connect to the Wi-Fi. 
Then, the hotspot name is automatically stored on my phone from that time on! 
Occasionally I glance through the list of all the museums, resorts, restaurants, and other places I’ve visited in my travels. 
Although I can’t connect to these hotspots when I get home, just catching a glimpse of one of their names on the list makes me excited. 
All the memories from that place come flooding into my mind, and I can remember exactly what it was like to be, for example, at that peaceful terrace near the shore in Bali. 
For a moment, it’s almost like I’m actually there!

Another thing / I / collect / might sound / strange: / Wi-Fi hotspots. 
다른 것은 / 내가 / 모으는 / 들릴지도 모른다 / 이상하게 / 와이파이 핫스팟이다
Whenever I / ’m / in a place / I / want / to remember, / I / purposely / connect / to the Wi-Fi. 
내가 / 있을 때마다 / 장소에 / 내가 / 원하는 / 기억하기를 / 나는 / 일부러 / 연결한다 / 와이파이에
Then, / the hotspot name / is automatically stored / on my phone / from that time on! 
그러면 / 핫스팟 이름은 / 자동적으로 저장된다 / 내 폰에 / 그 때부터
Occasionally / I / glance through / the list / of all the museums, resorts, restaurants, and other places / I /’ve visited / in my travels. 
가끔 / 나는 / 쭉 훑어본다 / 목록을 / 모든 박물관, 리조트, 식당, 그리고 다른 장소들의 / 내가 / 방문했던 / 내 여행에서 
Although I / can’t connect / to these hotspots / when I / get / home, / just catching a glimpse / of one of their names on the list / makes / me / excited. 
나는 / 비록 연결할 수 없지만 / 이 핫스팟들에 / 내가 집에 돌아오면 / 그저 힐끗 보는 것은 / 리스트에 있는 그들의 이름들 중 하나를 / 만든다 / 나를 / 신나게
All the memories / from that place / come flooding / into my mind, / and / I / can remember / exactly / what it was like to be, / for example, / at that peaceful terrace / near the shore in Bali. 
모든 추억들이 / 그 장소에서의 / 밀려들어온다 / 내 마음속으로 / 그리고 / 나는 / 기억할 수 있다 / 정확히 / 있는 것이 어땠는지 / 예를 들어 / 평화로운 테라스에 / 발리 해변 근처의
For a moment, / it ’s almost like I’m actually there!
잠시 동안 /  마치 내가 실제로 그곳에 있는 것 같다

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

In the end, travel is really about personal memories and unique experiences that will color your soul and enrich your life. 
So the next time you think about grabbing a souvenir as a reminder of your trip, remember: whatever captures your own priceless moments will be better than any souvenir you can easily buy with money.

In the end, / travel / is really about personal memories and unique experiences / that will color / your soul / and / enrich / your life. 
결국 / 여행은 / 정말로 개인적인 추억과 특별한 경험에 관한 것이다 / 물들이는 / 너의 영혼을 / 그리고 / 풍요롭게 하는 / 너의 삶을
So the next time you / think / about grabbing a souvenir / as a reminder / of your trip, / remember: / whatever captures your own priceless moments / will be better / than any souvenir / you / can easily buy / with money.
그러니 / 다음번에 당신이 / 생각할 때 / 기념품을 급히 사는 것에 대해 / 기억을 떠올리는 것으로 / 너의 여행의 / 기억해라 / 너의 소중한 순간들을 담아내는 것은 무엇이든 / 더 나을 것이다 / 다른 어떤 기념품보다 / 너가 / 쉽게 살수 있는 / 돈으로

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

There was once a king who wanted to know three things: the right time to do everything, the most necessary people to pay attention to, and the most important thing to do.
He thought that knowing these things would ensure his success.
He announced that he would reward anyone who could teach him these things.
Many people traveled to his palace, but they all provided different answers to his questions.
Regarding the first question, some said that the king should make a detailed schedule so that he could always know the perfect time to do everything.
Others claimed that he should take every situation into account and wait for the precise moment to act.
Still others suggested that he should consult wise men.

There was once a king / who wanted to know / three things: / the right time / to do everything, / the most necessary people / to pay attention to, / and / the most important thing / to do.
이전에 왕이 있었다 / 알기를 원하는 / 세 가지를 / 적절한 시기 / 모든 것을 할 / 가장 필요한 사람 / 주의를 기울여야 할 / 그리고 / 가장 중요한 것 / 해야 할
He / thought / that knowing these things / would ensure / his success.
그는 / 생각했다 / 이런 것들을 아는 것은 / 보장 할 것이라고 / 그의 성공을
He / announced / that he / would reward / anyone / who could teach / him / these things.
그는 / 발표했다 / 그가 / 보상 할 것이라고 / 누구에게나 / 가르쳐 줄 수 있는 / 그에게 / 이런 것들을
Many people / traveled / to his palace, / but / they all / provided / different answers / to his questions.
많은 사람들은 / 방문했다 / 그의 궁전에 / 그러나 / 그들 모두 / 제공했다 / 다른 정답들을 / 그의 질문들에
Regarding the first question, / some / said / that the king / should make / a detailed schedule / so that he / could always know / the perfect time / to do everything.
첫 번째 질문에 관해서 / 몇몇은 / 말했다 / 왕이 / 짜야한다고 / 상세한 일정을 / 그가 / 항상 알 수 있기 위해서 / 적절한 시기를 / 모든 것을 할
Others / claimed / that he / should take every situation into account / and / wait / for the precise moment / to act.
다른 사람들은 / 주장했다 / 그가 / 모든 상황을 고려해야 한다고 / 그리고 / 기다려야 한다고 / 적절한 시기를 / 행동 할
Still others / suggested / that he / should consult / wise men.
또 다른 사람들은 / 제안했다 / 그가 / 상의해야 한다고 / 현자들과

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

When he awoke in the morning, the man was staring at him. "Forgive me," the man begged.
"I don't know you, and I have no reason to forgive you," the king replied.
"You might not know me, but I know you," the man answered.
"During the last war, you killed my brother and took my property.
When I knew that you had gone to see the hermit, I decided to kill you on your way back.
However, I came across your bodyguards, who recognized me and wounded me.
Although I escaped, I would have died if you hadn't saved my life.
Now, my sons and I will serve you forever."
Pleased to have made friends with his enemy so easily, the king forgave the man and promised to restore his property.
After the man left, the king went outside to talk to the hermit.

When he / awoke / in the morning, / the man / was staring / at him. / "Forgive me," / the man / begged.
그가 / 일어났을 때 / 아침에 / 그 남자는 / 바라고보 있었다 / 그를 / 저를 용서해 주세요 / 남자가 / 빌었다
"I / don't know / you, / and / I / have / no reason / to forgive you," / the king / replied.
나는 / 알지못해 / 당신을 / 그리고 / 나는 / 이유가 없다 / 용서할 / 왕이 / 대답했다
"You / might not know / me, / but / I / know / you," / the man / answered.
당신은 / 모를수 있다 / 나를 / 그러나 / 나는 / 안다 / 당신을 / 그 남자는 / 대답했다
"During the last war, / you / killed / my brother / and / took / my property.
지난 전쟁동안 / 너는 / 죽였다 / 내 형제를 / 그리고 / 가져갔다 / 나의 재산을
When I / knew / that you / had gone / to see the hermit, / I / decided / to kill / you / on your way back.
내가 / 알았을 때 / 당신이 / 갔었다는 것을 / 은자를 보기위해서 / 나는 / 결심했다 / 당신을 죽이기로 / 당신이 돌아오는 길에
However, / I / came across / your bodyguards, / who recognized / me / and / wounded / me.
그러나 / 나는 / 우연히 마주쳤다 / 당신의 경호원들을 / 알아봤다 / 나를 / 그리고 / 상처를 입혔다 / 나에게
Although I escaped, / I / would have died / if you / hadn't saved / my life.
비록 내가 / 탈출했지만 / 나는 / 죽었을 것이다 / 만약 당신이 / 구해주지 않았더라면 / 내 목숨을
Now, / my sons / and / I / will serve / you / forever."

Pleased to have made friends / with his enemy / so easily, / the king / forgave / the man / and / promised / to restore his property.

After the man / left, / the king / went outside / to talk / to the hermit.

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

Towering over the East River, the Brooklyn Bridge is one of New York City's famous landmarks.
Nowadays, many people take it for granted, but back in the 1800s it was something people only dreamt of.
The bridge's construction cost more than $320 million in today's money and the lives of over two dozen people.
In particular, the family in charge of the project paid a high price to create the impressive bridge we all know and love today.
This is the story of how the Roeblings built the Brooklyn Bridge.
In the 1860s, the populations of Manhattan and Brooklyn were rapidly increasing, and so was the number of the commuters between them.
Thousands of people took boats and ferries across the East River every day, but these forms of transport were unstable and frequently stopped by bad weather.
Many New Yorkers wanted to have a bridge directly connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn because it would make their commute quicker and safer.
Unfortunately, because of the East River's great width and rough tides, it would be difficult to build anything on it.
It was also a very busy river at that time, with hundreds of ships constantly sailing on it.

Towering over the East River, / the Brooklyn Bridge / is one / of New York City's famous landmarks.
이스트 강 위로 솓아있는 / 브루클린 다리는 / 하나이다 / 뉴욕시의 명소들 중
Nowadays, / many people / take it for granted, / but / back in the 1800s / it / was something / people only dreamt of.
요즘 / 많은 사람들은 / 그것을 당연하게 여긴다 / 그러나 / 1800년대에 / 그것은 / 무언가였다 / 사람들이 그저 꿈꾸기만 했던
The bridge's construction / cost / more than $320 million / in today's money / and / the lives / of over two dozen people.
그 다리의 건설은 / 비용이 들었다 / 3억 2천만 달러 이상의 / 현재의 가치로 / 그리고 / 목숨 
In particular, / the family / in charge of the project / paid / a high price / to create the impressive bridge / we all / know / and / love / today.
특히 / 가족은 / 그 프로젝트의 책임을 맡은 / 치렀다 / 큰 대가를 / 인상적인 다리를 만들기 위해 / 우리 모두가 / 알고 있는 / 그리고 / 사랑하는 / 오늘날
This / is the story / of how the Roeblings / built / the Brooklyn Bridge.
이것은 / 이야기이다 / 어떻게 Roebling 가문이 / 건설했는지 / 브루클린 다리를
In the 1860s, / the populations / of Manhattan and Brooklyn / were rapidly increasing, / and / so was the number / of the commuters / between them.

Thousands of people / took / boats / and / ferries / across the East River / every day, / but / these forms / of transport / were unstable / and / frequently stopped / by bad weather.
수천명의 사람들이 / 탔다 / 배를 / 그리고 / 페리를 / 이스트 강을 건너 / 매일 / 그러나 / 이런 형태는 / 수송 수단의 / 불안정했다 / 그리고 / 자주 멈췄다 / 악천후에 의해
Many New Yorkers / wanted / to have a bridge / directly connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn / because / it / would make / their commute / quicker and safer.
많은 뉴욕 시민들은 / 원했다 / 다리를 갖기를 / 맨하튼과 브루클린을 연결하는 / 왜냐하면 / 그것은 / 만들어 줄 것이기 때문이었다 / 그들의 통근을 / 더 빠르고 안전하게
Unfortunately, / because of the East River's great width and rough tides, / it / would be difficult / to build anything / on it.
불행히도 / 이스트 강의 넓은 폭과 거친 물살 때문에 / 그것은 / 어려웠을 것이다 / 무언가를 짓는 것이 / 그 위에
It / was also a very busy river / at that time, / with hundreds of ships / constantly sailing / on it.

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

Luckily, John's role as chief engineer was succeeded by his son, Washington Roebling.
Because he had built bridges with his father and studied bridge construction in Europe, he believed in John's dream.
At that time, the foundations for the bridge's two towers were being built in the East River, which was extremely difficult and dangerous work.
Workers had to stay at the bottom of the river in a waterproof box with little light and constant danger.
Many died or were permanently injured by a serious disease called "the bends," including Washington Roebling.
In 1872, he developed this disease and was unable to move easily or visit the construction sites throughout the rest of the project.
Other people would have quit at that point, but not Washington.
He continued to supervise the bridge building for years by watching it through a telescope from his bedroom.
However, there were still many things he could not do despite all his efforts.
Once again, the project seemed likely to be abandoned.

Luckily, / John's role / as chief engineer / was succeeded / by his son, / Washington Roebling.
다행히도 / John의 역할은 / 수석 엔지니어로서의 / 이어졌다 / 그의 아들에 의해서 / Washingtom Robling
Because he / had built / bridges / with his father / and / studied / bridge construction / in Europe, / he / believed / in John's dream.
그가 / 건설했었기 때문에 / 다리를 / 그의 아빠와 / 그리고 / 공부했었기 때문에 / 교량 건설을 / 유럽에서 / 그는 / 믿었다 / John의 꿈을
At that time, / the foundations / for the bridge's two towers / were being built / in the East River, / which was extremely difficult and dangerous work.
그 당시에 / 기반은 / 다리의 두 개 탑을 위한 / 지어지고 있었다 / 이스트 강에서 / 굉장히 어렵고 위험한 일인
Workers / had to stay / at the bottom of the river / in a waterproof box / with little light / and / constant danger.
노동자들은 / 머물러야만 했다 / 강의 바닥에 / 방수 처리된 박스 안에서 / 거의 없는 불빛과 함께 / 그리고 / 끊임없는 위험과 함께
Many / died / or / were permanently injured / by a serious disease / called "the bends," / including Washington Roebling.
많은 사람들은 / 죽었다 / 또는 / 영구적으로 부상을 당했다 / 심각한 질병에 의해 / 잠함병이라고 불리는 / Washington Roebling을 포함한
In 1872, / he / developed / this disease / and / was unable / to move easily / or / visit the construction sites / throughout the rest / of the project.
1872년에 / 그는 / 걸렸다 / 그 병에 / 그리고 / 불가능했다 / 쉽게 움직이는 것이 / 또는 / 건설 현장을 방문하는 것이 / 남은 기간 내내 / 프로젝트의
Other people / would have quit / at that point, / but / not Washington.
다른 사람들은 / 포기 했을 것이다 / 그 시점에서 / 그러나 / Washington은 그렇지 않았다
He / continued to supervise / the bridge building / for years / by watching it / through a telescope / from his bedroom.
그는 / 계속해서 감독했다 / 다리 건설을 / 수 년간 / 그것을 바라보면서 / 망원경을 통해 / 그의 침실에서
However, / there were still many things / he / could not do / despite all his efforts.
그러나 / 여전히 많은 것들이 있었다 / 그가 / 할 수 없는 / 그의 모든 노력에도 불구하고 
Once again, / the project / seemed likely to be abandoned.
또다시 / 그 프로젝트는 / 포기될 것처럼 보였다

The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. 	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

To everyone's amazement, yet another Roebling stepped in to save the bridge.
This time, it was Washington's wife, Emily Warren Roebling.
She believed in what her family had started, and she was determined to see it through.
Before marriage, she knew almost nothing about engineering.
As her husband's health failed, though, Emily began passing his instructions to the assistant engineers and bringing back their construction reports.
In the process, she naturally picked up a lot of information about bridge building.
With his assistance, she also studied higher mathematics and engineering so hard that she became an expert in them without ever going to college!
By the time the bridge was finished in 1883, Emily was carrying out many of the chief engineer's duties, which was unprecedented for a woman in those days.
Many people praised her contributions to the project, and she became the first person to cross the bridge.
It was the moment she, Washington, John, and everyone else who built the bridge had worked so hard for.

To everyone's amazement, / yet another Roebling / stepped in / to save the bridge.
놀랍게도 / 또 다른 한명의 Roebling이 / 돕고 나섰다 / 다리를 구해내기 위해
This time, / it / was Washington's wife, / Emily Warren Roebling.
이번엔 / 그것은 / Washington의 아내 / Emily Warren Roebling이었다
She / believed in / what her family / had started, / and / she / was determined / to see it through.
그녀는 / 믿었다 / 그녀의 가족이 / 시작했던 것을 / 그리고 / 그녀는 / 결심했다 / 끝까지 해내겠다고
Before marriage, / she / knew almost nothing / about engineering.
결혼 전에 / 그녀는 / 거의 알지 못했다 / 공학 기술에 대해서
As her husband's health / failed, / though, / Emily / began / passing his instructions / to the assistant engineers / and / bringing back / their construction reports.
그녀 남편의 건강이 / 악화되자 / 하지만 / Emily는 / 시작했다 / 그의 지시를 전달하는 것을 / 보조 엔지니어들에게 / 그리고 / 가지고 돌아오는 것을 / 그들의 건축 보고를
In the process, / she / naturally picked up / a lot of information / about bridge building.
그 과정에서 / 그녀는 / 자연스럽게 습득했다 / 많은 정보를 / 다리 건설에 대한

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

In today's world, there is a lot of statistical information around us all the time. 
Every time we read an article on the Internet or see a commercial on TV, we are likely to come into contact with numbers and figures. 
Generally, these numbers help us make better decisions in our daily lives. 
For example, when we choose which movie to see, we can check the ratings and see the reviews of thousands of viewers. 
Similarly, when people see statistics that show fastening a seat belt greatly increases the chances of surviving a car accident, they may choose to wear one themselves. 
These are just a few examples of how statistical information plays an important role in our lives. 
However, is it safe to believe statistics exactly the way they are presented to us? 
Unfortunately, statistics can be misused in many ways. 
Let's learn about some common tricks behind statistics.

In today’s world, / there is a lot of statistical information / around us / all the time.
오늘날의 세상에는 / 많은 통계적 정보가 있다 / 우리 주위에 / 항상
Every time we read / an article / on the Internet / or / see / a commercial / on TV, / we / are likely to come into contract with / numbers and figures.
우리가 읽을 때마다 / 기사를 / 인터넷으로 / 혹은 / 볼 때마다 / 광고를 / TV에서 / 우리는 / 접하기 쉽다 / 숫자들과 수치들을
Generally, / these numbers / help / us / make / better decisions / in our daily lives. 
일반적으로, / 이러한 숫자들은 / 도와준다 / 우리가 / 내리도록 / 더 나은 결정을 / 일상생활에서
For example, / when we / choose / which movie to see, / we / can check / the ratings / and / see / the reviews / of thousands / of viewers. 
예를 들어, / 우리가 /  고를 때 / 어떤 영화를 볼지, / 우리는 / 확인할 수 있다 / 평점을 / 그리고 / 볼 수 있다 / 후기를 / 수천 명의 / 관객들의
Similarly, / when people / see / statistics / that show / fastening a seat belt / greatly / increases / the chances / of surviving a car accident, / they / may choose to wear / one / themselves. 
마찬가지로, / 사람들이 / 볼 때, / 통계 자료를 / 보여주는 / 안전벨트를 착용하는 것이 / 크게 / 높여준다는 것을 / 가능성을 / 차 사고에서 생존의 / 사람들은 / 택할지도 모른다 / 착용하는 것을 / 그것을 / 스스로

Unfortunately, / statistics / can be misused / in many ways.

The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

People can also get the wrong idea from statistics when a sample is not random. 
For example, a restaurant may put survey cards on the tables, hoping to know what most customers think about its food, service, or atmosphere. 
However, few cards will be filled out by normal customers, because they don't have any reason to do so. 
Only those with strongly positive or negative reactions are likely to respond to the survey. 
This method of choosing a sample is called “voluntary response sampling.” 
Such samples are biased in favor of strong opinions and underrepresent the moderate ones. 
Therefore, when you see a statistic, remember that the sample is just as important as the statistic itself. 
How many people were in the sample? Who were they? If you don't know, be careful not to leap to conclusions.

People / can also get / the wrong idea / from statistics / when a sample / is not random. 
사람들은 / 또한 얻을 수 있다 / 잘못된 생각을 / 통계로부터 / 표본이 / 무작위가 아닐 때
For example, / a restaurant / may put / survey cards / on the tables, / hoping to know / what most customers / think / about its food, service, or atmosphere. 
예를 들어, 한 식당이 / 올려놓을 수 있다 / 설문조사 카드를 / 식탁위에 / 알기를 희망하며 / 대부분의 고객들이 / 어떻게 생각하는지를 / 그들의 음식, 서비스, 분위기에 대해서
However, / few cards / will be filled out / by normal customers, / because they / don't have / any reason / to do so. 
하지만, / 카드들은 / 거의 작성되지 않을 것이다 / 일반적인 고객들로부터 / 왜냐하면 그들은 / 가지고 있지 않다 / 어떤 이유도 / 그렇게 할
Only those / with strongly positive or negative reactions / are likely to respond / to the survey. 
오직 고객들만이 / 강하게 긍정적이거나 부정적인 의견을 가진  / 응할 가능성이 있다 / 그 조사에
This method / of choosing a sample / is called / “voluntary response sampling.” 
이러한 방식은 / 표본을 고르는 / 불린다 / ‘자발적 응답 표본 추출’이라고
Such samples / are biased / in favor of strong opinions / and underrepresent / the moderate ones. 
이러한 표본들은 / 편향되고 / 강한 의견에 유리하게 / 그리고 적게 표시한다 / 중간의 의견들을
Therefore, / when you / see / a statistic, / remember / that the sample / is just as important as / the statistic / itself.

Who / were they?
누구였는가 / 그들은 
If you / don't know, / be careful / not to leap  to conclusions.
당신이 / 알지 못한다면 / 조심해라 / 급히 결론을 내리지 않도록

Your task is to help Korean users practice direct translation (직독직해) by breaking down English sentences into meaning units and providing Korean translations aligned with those units. The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

Example:

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

ABC Corporation wants to hire some employees. 
In order to look like a well-paying company and to recruit competent candidates, the company decides to distribute a press release that says the average yearly salary of its employees is $57,000, which is quite high. 
However, the fact is that more than half of its employees earn no more than $30,000 or less a year, and the most common salary for employees is only $20,000.
Did the company spread false information? How is this possible? 
It's because the company used the trap of averages. 
Averages can show different pictures depending on which type is chosen. 
To understand the meaning of different types of averages, let's look at the illustration on the next page.

ABC Corporation / wants to hire / some employees. 
ABC 기업은 / 고용하기를 원한다 / 몇몇 직원들을
In order to look like / a well-paying company / and to recruit / competent candidates, / the company / decides to distribute / a press release / that says / the average yearly salary / of its employees / is $57,000, / which is quite high. 
보이기 위해서 / 보수가 좋은 회사처럼 / 그리고 모집하기 위해서 / 유능한 지원자들을 / 그 회사는 / 배포하기로 결정했다 / 보도 자료를 / 말하는 / 평균 연봉이 / 자사 직원들의 / $57,000달러 임을 / 이는 꽤 높은 금액이다.
However, / the fact / is that more than half of its employees / earn / no more than $30,000 / or less / a year, / and the most common salary / for employees / is only $20,000.
하지만, / 사실은 / 회사 직원들 중 절반 이상이 / 번다는 것이다 / 겨우 $30,000 / 혹은 그 이하를 / 일 년에 / 그리고 가장 흔한 연봉은 / 직원들에게 / 고작 $20,000에 불과하다
Did the company / spread / false information?  
회사가 / 퍼뜨린 것인가 / 거짓 정보를
How is / this / possible? 
어떻게 / 이것이 / 가능한가
It / 's because the company / used / the trap / of averages. 
그것은 / 회사가 / 사용했기 때문이다 / 함정을 / 평균의
Averages / can show / different pictures / depending on which type is chosen. 
평균은 / 보여줄 수 있다 / 다른 상황을 / 어느 유형이 선택되었는지에 따라
To understand / the meaning / of different types / of averages, / let's look / at the illustration / on the next page.

The English text should be split into logical chunks for easier comprehension, and the Korean translation should follow the same structure, ensuring clarity and flow. Avoid complex grammar explanations; focus on providing intuitive and straightforward translations.

Instructions:

	1.	Break English sentences into logical meaning units (short phrases or clauses).
	2.	Provide a Korean translation immediately after each English unit.
	3.	Ensure that the Korean translation aligns closely with the English meaning units to help the user easily match the two.
	4.	Keep both English and Korean translations simple and clear.

English: “One of the best things / that travel gives us / is the memories of the places / we’ve visited / and / the special experiences / we had there.”

Korean: “최고의 것들 중 하나는 / 여행이 우리에게 주는 / 장소의 기억들이다 / 우리가 방문했던 / 그리고 / 특별한 경험들이다 / 우리가 그곳에서 가졌던.”

Keep sentences concise and avoid unnecessary elaborations. Your goal is to make the direct translation practice effective and easy to follow.

In mass media, graphs are often used because they display data more efficiently than tables of raw data do.
However, graphs can be misleading, too. Let's look at the two graphs below.
The two graphs shown here illustrate how data can be misrepresented.
In the first graph, the vertical axis goes all the way up to 100 and all the way down to 0, which makes the decrease in the percentage look modest.
In the other graph, only 10 percentage points are shown, from 65 to 75, which makes the change seem much more extreme.
Notable is the fact that the two graphs are based on exactly the same data.
So, if you want to point out the seriousness of skipping breakfast, you can use the second graph.
In fact, you can make nearly any graph more convincing in favor of your argument by cutting off the graph at a certain point. Hence, whenever you see a graph, you should check the units on the vertical and horizontal axes to see what the highest and lowest values are. 
Don't simply assume the visual impact is the same as the real story. 
Check whether the graph is presented in a specific way to emphasize a point.

In mass media, / graphs / are often used / because they / display / data / more efficiently / than tables / of raw data / do.
대중 매체에서 / 도표들은 / 자주 사용된다 / 왜냐하면 그들이 / 보여주기 때문이다 / 자료를 / 더 효율적으로 / 표가 / 원 자료의 / 보여주는 것보다
However, / graphs / can be misleading, / too.  
하지만, / 도표도 / 오해를 불러 일으킬 수 있다 / 또한
Let's look at / the two graphs / below.
살펴보자 / 두 개의 도표를 / 아래의

In the first graph, / the vertical axis / goes / all the way up to 100 / and all the way down to 0 / , which makes / the decrease / in the percentage / look / modest.
첫 번째 도표에서 / 새로 축은 / 이어진다 / 위로는 100까지 / 그리고 아래로는 0까지 / 그리고 그것은 만든다 / 감소가 / 백분율에서의 / 보이도록 / 완만하게
In the other graph, / only 10 percentage points / are shown, / from 65 to 75 / , which makes / the change / seem / much more extreme.

When people state opinions in articles, speeches, debates, or advertisements, they often give some statistics to support or reinforce their point. 
If these statistics are found through proper research methods, then they are objective facts. 
However, many statistics that you see and hear could just be numbers that are meant to convince you of a certain view. 
Therefore, the next time you come across some statistics, don't blindly accept any data that is presented. 
Look at the statistics in detail with a critical eye, and then judge whether or not they are convincing.

When people / state / opinions / in articles, speeches, debates, or advertisements, / they / often / give / some statistics / to support or reinforce their point.
사람들이 / 말할 때, / 의견을 / 기사, 연설, 토론, 또는 광고에서 / 그들은 / 종종 / 제시한다 / 몇몇 통계 자료를 / 그들의 의견을 뒷받침하거나 강화하기 위해 
If these statistics / are found / through proper research methods, / then / they / are objective facts.
만약 이러한 통계자료들이 / 얻어지면 / 적절한 연구 방법을 통해 / 그러면 / 그들은 / 객관적인 사실이 된다.
